Una de las cosas que me enamor√≥ de bioshock fue su historia y el c√≥mo enlazaban detalles entre los 2 juegos anteriores. Si bien este tiene una historia interesante, no tiene mayor relaci√≥n a los anteriores (CASI NADA, por no decir nada), y al momento de terminarlo sent√≠ que fue una gran p√©rdida de tiempo el haber esperado algo similar a lo que me hab√≠a producido en cuanto a emoci√≥n y entretenci√≥n esta saga anteriormente.

Great conclusion to the Bioshock Series for me. Combat didn't feel as good as in the originals in the series. I personally don't feel the need to play any of the DLC. Combat was enough of a turn off in general that I played this to 'complete' the series and move on to other games. All in all, happy I bought it when it was on sale. Engrossing story, interesting conclusion.

This game along with the ENTIRE Bioshock series is hands down my favorite game/series ever. I can replay them over and over again and never get tired of the story and immersive gameplay. The concept of Rapture is amazing and they never fail to impress.

So this is one of my all time favorite games.  Is it one of the best games ever made?  Oh no no sweet child, no.  Is it one of the best stories told through a video game ever made?  You bet your sweet [strike]plasmids[/strike] shit [i]salts[/i].  My bad.

so at the risk of sounding pretentious, here is my indepth analysis of Bioshock Infinite 

The game play of this Bioshock is vastly different from the past two games.  It's more similar to Bioshock 2 in the way it feels except you don't need to protect a little sister cause Elizabeth is a grown, independant woman (with a waist the diameter of a quarter).  It feels like a Bioshock game in the way the setting is illustrated and the way that the game controls, but other than that it's very different. 
First off, you aren't in Rapture, you're in Columbia.  A giant floating "utopia" in the sky.  Now the story telling aspect of this decision is genius.  It mirrors Rapture.  Instead of building a utopia at the bottom of the sea, you do it in the sky.  Andrew Ryan/Comstock; Rapture/Columbia; Big Daddys/Handy Men-wait... *Jontron* oh no... this leads me into my next topic

The strategy, expansive maps you want to explore and reward you by exploring with audiologs are now gone.  The feeling of accomplishment after you stalk a Big Daddy for fifteen, twenty minutes waiting for him to collect a little sister and making [b]YOUR OWN DECISION[/b] about engaging these enimies based off of how ready you are is all gone.  This game has revoked the decision making that the first two Bioshocks gave you and just throws wave after wave of enemies at you, but it does compensate.  This is where most of the Bioshock fan boys get their panties in a twist (my self included).  The game reduces itself into a much more linear shoot-em-up style game, much different from the intelligent and smooth decision based format of the original two Bioshocks.  

A lot of people hate this change and I agree that Infinite's gameplay is far inferior to its predicessors.  [b]BUT[/b], hear me out, this is a different kind of game.  The first two Bioshock games were setting based stories, focused on telling the story of Rapture and its inhabitents, what happened to the once great metropolis, and the plasmids and their effect on the underwater society.  Much like Bungie era Halo games, Bioshock gives you an intriguing character, barely fleshed out enough that you can project yourself into them.  You are able to become this character (or the character become you) and make your decisions in combat or how you want to progress.  You unravel the mystery of your surroundings and answer the questions you have about it.  The use of the audiologs in this game were genius and allowed you to fill in gaps and stories of other characters within the setting without having to sit through a cutscene or be bogged down with backstory.  It lets you [i]decide[/i] to invest yourself in the story.  
However, Infinite is a [u]character driven narrative[/u].  Yeah the gameplay is less intriguing and fresh, the enimies are far less interesting and multilayered, and yes Columbia is not nearly as mind-fuckingly cool as Rapture is.  But you aren't there for those aspects of the game.  You are there for Booker and Elizabeth.  You are playing the game to hear their story and to see their characters develop, not to see Columbia's story (this is why the audiologs in Infinite were pointless and kind of irritating.  You didn't care what they had to say because you weren't there for the setting, you were there for the characters that you were playing and watching, not the side characters).  And in a way, I also think this is genius.  It mirrors Rapture even MORE.  Ken Levine did an amazing job crafting these narratives and I think he made the right choice about passing on involvement in Bioshock 2.  In my opinion, same as Levine's, they had said all that needed to be said about Rapture.  If there were just 2 games that so gracefully mirror themselves in almost every aspect, it would be a work of art.  But I just have this feeling 2K wanted to repeat the success of the first Bioshock and wanted to go with the safe route, making more of the same thing ensuring more money is made and less risks are taken.  This led to the relitively uneccessary and fluff filler middle child.  The gameplay of Bioshock 2 was streamlined and an improvement on the fantastic gameplay of the first, but yeah it was kinda not needed.

The argument can be made that you're playing a video game and the first priority of a game is to be fun and fresh, something enjoyable to play and not just something to watch, and yeah I agree.  I'm not saying Infinite is not without its faults because gaddamn the promotional trailers and teases looked like they had a much much MUCH more interesting gameplay.  But can we all just sit down and take a moment to appreciate Infinite for what it is?  One of the best stories told in gaming history.  

Do I like Infinite more than Bioshock one or two?  No (well, maybe more than two).  Do I love Infinite?  Yes, with all of my heart.  

Overall, the hate this game recieves in my opinion is childish and petty.  Get over yourself and let the story engage you.  Allow all of your mental faculties and orifaces to be filled with this brain twisting mind-fuck.  Allow yourself to hear Booker and Elizebeth's story.  Don't get all butt-hurt about the changes because it is a different game.  It's its own game.

The only game, that shocked me so hard at the end, that I had to stand up, walk away and think everything through and start to realize to what actually happened.

What a great follow-up to the Bioshock series. Bioshock Infinite manages to keep it's Bioshock roots while also adding new stuff. First, the setting: While the underwater city of Rapture was cool to travel, i preferred Columbia, the city in the clouds. It's way more colorful and open, especially in the beginning, when you're exploring it. The story is one of the best in videogame history, with great characters, especially your companion, Elizabeth. The game is more linear, but that means it's more focused. The graphics and music aren't the greatest, but they work pretty well. The gameplay it's similar to its predecessors, mixing gunplay and spells, however you're only limited to 2 weapons at once, which i didn't like. But overall, it's a great game that i recommend even if you haven't played the original Bioshock.
There's also 3 pieces of major DLC: Clash in the Clouds, which is a challenge mode in four maps with 15 waves each, plus some optional challenges. It's tough, but that should be expected. The Burial at Sea episodes are more interesting. Episode 1 feels like an expansion, but this time the setting is Rapture, and you get to see it before the events of the original Bioshock. It‚Äôs good, but nothing really special. Episode 2, however, is great. You play as Elizabeth, and the gameplay is stealth focused, which i found refreshing. It's longer than Episode 1, but what i enjoyed the most was its story, managing to add events from Bioshock Infinite and serving as an actual prequel to the original Bioshock. There's also a great, discomfortable scene. Clash in the Clouds is filler content, and you need to play the original Bioshock first to fully enjoy the Burial at Sea episodes. But i also recommend you to get those.
